140.35.text:
First of all, I'd like to explain to you how
induction loops work.

144.81.text:
What we have here, is a guy, a bit like me,
I suppose, speaking into microphone,

149.82.text:
a very directional microphone, that should
be picking up just my voice and

154.90.text:

other people speaking and so on, and feeding
a nice clean signal into

163.95.text:
That amplifier happens to be a current amplifier,

169.23.text:
That current amplifier drives the current
through a cable.

172.34.text:
The cable is placed around the audience in
it's simplistic terms.

178.96.text:
That current sets up a magnetic field, which
in turn, induces a current

187.64.text: into the pickup coil of the hearing aid.

190.54.text:
The current is being modulated
by the person's voice.

193.44.text:
So we've got this modulated signal, an audio
signal

197.10.text: fed into the pickup coil of the hearing aid.

202.26.text:
That signal is then going to be
tonally corrected for the person's hearing

206.24.text:
loss, amplified, and via a speaker
fed into the person's ear.

211.93.text:
And that's simply how an induction loop system
works.

353.05.text: Where are hearing loops not suitable then?

358.77.text:
Hearing loops are the first choice

364.75.text:
In some cases, they're
the only option, if we have a transient environment,

370.26.text:
where people
are only going to be there for a few minutes,

374.21.text:
it's not feasible,
it's not practical to issue them a receiver

377.06.text:
to use that system for those few
minutes that they are in that facility.

381.36.text:
So currently, the only option we have
is to use induction loop technology.

387.42.text:
However, places where they shouldn't
be used.

391.72.text:
If the background magnetic noise is too high,
there is absolutely no

397.26.text: point in installing an induction loop system.

So when we--the first thing

1165.76.text:

That's telling us that if the current in the
